text: The whole island, from the south.  For a second.  Literal
Closer, just the skyline.  For another second.
Closer still, the Upper West Side.  For another second. time to waste admiring the scenery.

Race across a field of PEDESTRIANS to pick up three women hurrying down the sidewalk.  LYDIA LYNCH, a real estate broker, vaults down the sidewalk, she's got a hell of a stride.  MEG ALTMAN, thirtyish, struggles to keep up with her, she's tall, wafer-thin, pale as a ghost.  SARAH, a n year old girl, flat out runs to keep up, dribbling a basketball as she goes.  The kid's athletic, much tougher than Meg, who she resembles. Lydia reads from a sheet she carries in her bouncing hand
-- seventeen feet wide, fifty-five feet deep, forty-two hundred square feet, four floors with a rentable basement apartment, so five altogether, courtyard in back --
Could you slow down a little? (looking back over her shoulder) Or we could wait for the car...
No cars.  Feet are faster.
How many more do we have after this?
None, there's nothing else, you know how tight the market is.
This is it?  I told you on the phone, I have to be moved in in two weeks.  Sarah, please don't bounce that here.
Mom, it's the sidewalk.
Oh, that miserable little prick is already leaving.

They approach a row of brownstones, narrow four story townhouses, nice looking buildings, a hundred years old o more.  EVAN, a sour-looking man, has just locked the fron door of number 26 and is coming down the steps.  He sees coming.
One day you will learn to respect other people's time, Lydia, one day you --
Evan, I am so sorry, you were a saint to wait for us!

Evan throws open the front door, revealing the airy foyer the townhouse.  The place is completely empty.  He talks fast, races through the tour.  The three of them come in, Sarah still bouncing her basketball.
This is the middle of the house, the entry floor, living room's over there.  The kitchen floor's below us and there's two bedroom floors above.
The front door closes behind them, with a THUD so authoritative it seems to say no one's ever getting out. tries to get her daughter's attention, to tell her to sto bouncing the ball in the house.
It's an enormous amount of space for the money and I'll be perfectly honest, the family is in no hurry whatsoever.
Meg whispers Sarah's name, but Sarah still ignores her, g on bouncing the ball.
I don't have to tell you there is an acute shortage of living space in Manhattan right now and this is a highly unique property.
No ball, kid.

Sarah immediately stops bouncing.  She wanders into the living room, peers through the big French doors, which lo out over the courtyard area.  There's another row of brownstones on the next block, and all the patios back up one another.  It looks tranquil out there, oasis in the c Sarah leans up against the door, sighs, her breath fogs t window.  There is a profound melancholy about her.  Meg watches her, tries to catch eyes with her in the reflecti Can't. Evan flings open the door of an old-fashioned cage-style elevator.
Working elevator.  Mr. Pearlstine, the previous owner, was disabled the last ten years of his life.  Highly unusual, the elevator, you will not find this in ninety percent of brownstones.
Will they take asking price?  I need a two week escrow and I'm already approved for the loan.
Lydia turns, gives Meg an "are you insane?" look.
What say we see the house before we dicker, hmm? (starting up the stairs) I have to warn you, this is exactly the response we expected to get. It's a very emotional property.
As he disappears upstairs, Lydia turns to Meg, lowers her voice.
Who taught you to negotiate?
It's not like Saks', Mom, you don't have to pay the price on the tag.

She gets in the elevator and RATTLES the door shut with a bang.  That kid's got an attitude.  Meg takes a deep brea turns to Lydia.  She brushes her hair behind an ear, we notice her thin hand is shaking.
I'm sorry.  Apartments, and... money, and... this is more my husband's area.
She digs in her purse for a prescription pill bottle and water.
Was.  His area.  I'm not very good at...
Lydia watches as she swallows a pill, waiting for Meg to finish her sentence.  Not very good at what?
Things, and if I can't prove to my soon to-be ex-husband that I can provide a suitable place for our daughter to live in the next fourteen days, it's going to get ugly between us.  Uglier.
Lydia just looks at her, no idea what to say.  These two from different places.
(from upstairs) It would be so lovely if I could shot the property before I leave!
Evan, Lydia, and Meg poke their heads in a series of room one after the other, the tour flying by quickly.  First, upstairs bedroom.  Nice, roomy, looks out on the courtyar
Top floor.  Two bedrooms, one bathroom.
Another floor, another empty room.  The trio passes throu
Third floor, spare bedroom, den, what have you.  Mr. Pearlstine used it as an office.
(low voice, to Meg) He's talking about Bernard Pearlstine.
Meg shrugs, who's that?
(moving, through a bathroom) Master bath.

The hotel guy?  It's been in the papers lately.  His kids are all suing each other over his estate. He was a total recluse, paranoid, rich as hell, he was worth thirty million or something, now it turns out they can't find half of it. (singsong) Somebody took something didn't belong to them!
I hardly see how family gossip is germane to showing the property.
(low, to Meg) Stop calling it the property, you sound ridiculous.
(through a closet) Master closet.

From the hallway, there is a GROANING METALLIC sound, the elevator, and the happy laughter of the little girl as sh puts it through its paces.  Evan winces, speaks as if his mouth hurts when he moves it.
Could the child please stop that?
KID!  NO ELEVATOR!
She looks at Meg and winks.
And we emerge in the master bedroom.

He checks his watch. Meg looks around, studying the dimensions of the room.  S looks at the far wall, the one that borders the house nex door.  She looks at the wall that corners it, opposite th window wall.  She takes two steps back from it.
Something's weird.
What?
I don't know, doesn't that corner seem funny to you?

She points to the far end of the wall, near the entrance the closet.  There is a mirrored door that leads to the closet, and a mirror on the wall alongside it.  If you lo closely, you'll see that the mirrors are raked slightly toward one another, which causes an optical illusion in w the corner of the room appears much closer to the door th it is.
I was waiting to see if you'd notice!  On caravan, no one from our office had the slightest idea.

He pushes on the top of the mirror on the wall.  It makes faint CLICK, then glides open a few inches off the wall. pulls it toward him, opens it all the way, a hundred eigh degrees, and it fastens magnetically to the back of the closed door.  There is smooth wall behind it, but if you closely, there is a faint vertical crack in the wall. Meg looks at him -- what in the world?  Even pushes again twice this time, first at the top, then at the bottom, an the smooth wall CLICKS ajar.  He pulls it wide open.  Meg Lydia step forward, fascinated.
From the opposite end of a lone, narrow, windowless space see the three of them standing in the open doorway, silhouetted by the sunlight streaming through the bedroom windows behind them.
It's called a panic room.
He hits a switch and a row of bulbs flick on overhead.
A what?
A safe room.  An inner sanctum.  A castle keep, in medieval times.
Oh, I've seen these...
It's quite in vogue in high end construction right now.  One really can't be too careful about home invasion.

The other two walk inside, but Meg lingers near the door, looking around, studying the neatly arrayed survival supp -- water, food packs, batteries, flashlights, tools, rope clothes, blankets -- you get the idea.

Hey, this is perfect for you... (Meg scoffs) Absolutely!  You're a woman, you're living alone now.  Your alarm goes off, or you head glass break, or for whatever reason you think someone's broken into your home in the middle of the night.  What are you going to do?  Call the police and wait until they get here on Tuesday?  Traipse downstairs in your sexy little underthings and check it out?  I think not!

Reinforced steel core walls.  Buried phone line, completely separate, not connected to the house's main line and never exposed throughout the house's infrastructure or outside the house -- you can call the police; nobody can cut you off. Your own ventilation system, complete with oxygen scrubber, so you've got plenty of fresh air for as long as you like.  And a bank of video monitors --
He hits a switch next to a dozen tiny video monitors, revealing a dozen different views of the house.
-- covering almost every corner of the house.
Meg nods, starting to sweat.
Makes me nervous.
Why?
Ever read any Poe?
I don't think so, but I love her album.
No, Edgar Allen.
(thinks) The furniture guy?
(giving up) What's to keep them from prying open the door?

Evan reaches past Meg and pushes a red button on the wall behind her.  With a sudden WHANG of steel, a heavy metal leaps out of a slot in the wall and SLAMS shut, like a submarine hatch.  A series of metal latches CLICK into pl inside it, from top to bottom, securing it into place.
Steel, four inches thick.
Meg takes a step back.  They're now enclosed in the room.
Everything's spring-loaded, even if the power's out it's fully functional.
Open it.
Old Bernie didn't miss a trick with this room, did he?
Open the door.
And with kids like he's got, no wonder he wanted a place to hide.
That's highly inappropriate.
I said open the door.
Evan hits a green button and the door GROANS slowly open, recoiling its massive spring, and revealing Sarah, the li girl, standing in the entryway, grinning widely.
My room.  Definitely my room.
She bolts in, just as her mother bolts out.
Meg stands just outside the door to the panic room, regai her composure.  Not crazy about tight spaces.  Which we already knew.
That door is a safely hazard.
Not at all.
He points.  There's a tiny red beam that shines across th doorway, one at shoulder height --
Infrared.  Like the beam in an elevator doorway.  Won't let the door close if something's blocking it.
-- and one at shin height.  Even bend down, blocks the on shin height with his hand.
Watch.
He reaches up, to push the close button, but with one han anchored at the floor, he can't quite reach it.
(to Lydia) Push that button for me, will you?
Don't!

Lydia pushes the close button, nothing happens.  Evan pul his hand put of the beam, takes a step back.  Lydia pushe the button again. WHANG!  The metal door rockets shut, the metallic slang reverberating in the room.  Almost immediately, the fake piece of wall HUMS shut, of its own accord, followed a mo later by the mirror, which detaches itself from the back the closet door and HUMS silently back into place, closin over the hidden door, making the corner of the room look a corner again. As the mirrored door closes, it shows Meg her own reflect She looks at herself, still rattled.  She wipes a trickle sweat from the side of her face.

The same house, two weeks later.  The entry floor is pile high with moving boxes.  Sarah and Meg lie sprawled out i the middle of the black and white tile, arms and legs spl wide, exhausted. They stare up at the ceiling, beat.
Too many stairs.
Got us in here, didn't I?
Shoulda got an apartment.
Well, I know that now.
Meg raises her hand to her face, she's got her cell phone her palm.
Battery's dead.
Meg picks up the wall phone in the kitchen, gets a dial t
The phone works. (to Sarah) Hey, I hooked up the phone.
(sarcastic) The crowd goes wild.
(ignoring the slight) 478...
Meg finishes dialing.  It rings, someone answers.
Perry's Pizza, please hold.

Night has fallen.  Meg and Sarah sit at a small table in middle of the kitchen, surrounded by packing boxes.  They pizza.  They chew, silently.  Sarah drinks a diet Dr. Pepper.  Meg finishes a glass of wine. Meg's eyes are moist.  Sarah notices.  She notices her noticing, shrugs.  I'm human, what do you want me to do, it? Sarah looks away, goes back to chewing.  After a moment:
Fuck him.
Don't.
Fuck her too.
Meg looks at her, not sure how to confront the open defia
I agree.  But don't.
Sarah stares at her for a moment, then goes back to eatin Meg picks up the bottle of wine. Sarah's eyes flick over and watch as wine GLUGS into her mother's glass.

Sarah's bedroom is full of unpacked boxes, but her twin b has been set up and Sarah is in it, hair wet, pajamas on. She reads from a book ("Tom Swift and His Repelatron Skyw while Meg, drowsy, lies next to her, listening.

"Tom's throat felt so dry and tight that it was a moment before he could make any sound come out.  "Dad!" He croaked.  "I'm - inside - the - machine!" "Great Scott!"  The elder scientist gasped.  He dashed across the laboratory and switched off the repelatron's motor.  "What happened, son?" "The Durafoam hardened, Dad. Get a solvent, quick -- you know the formula!"

In the master bathroom, Meg soaks in a bath.  She is exhausted.  She reaches for her wine glass, finishes the of it. She stretches for the bottle, which is on the floor next her.  She refills the glass.  Again.
Meg, dressed in an old Knicks T-shirt and boxer shorts, stands next to the alarm panel in the master bedroom, rea from an instruction manual.  She's frustrated.  She mutte slurring, a bit drunk.
Bypass non-ready zones... shunt, enter, zone number...
She tries it, pushing a few buttons, but the alarm panel BEEPS at her disapprovingly.  She's doing something wrong She sighs, sits on the floor, gets serious about figuring the instructions.
Bypass non-ready zones... ah, shunt, enter, shunt again, zone number... wait...
dance over the alarm panel, some time later.  She seems t have figured it out, and a small light on the panel light up.
The very moment the red light goes on, we cut sharply to

-- the darkened panic room, where the dozen small video screens all suddenly wink to life, showing a dozen views the house.  Whatever she pushed turned these on too, prob not what she meant to do, but at least she got the alarm for the night. The door that leads from the panic room to the master bed hangs open.  In the middle of the floor in here, somebody made a small tent of blankets and couch cushions.  Sarah have been playing here before bed.

Meg puts sheets on her bed in the master bedroom. She fills a glass of water, puts it on a box she's using a night table. She plugs in a battery charger for her cell phone, places phone in the cradle.  It BEEPS.  "Charging." She sets the digital clock, puts it next to the glass of water.  It's 12:26. She gets in bed, her side, the left side. She lies in the dark, half an acre of empty bed across fr her. We drift off her, see the clock again.  The time changes, number one dissolves away, changing the time to --

-- 2:26.  Meg is in a hard, boozy sleep.  We drift out th door of the master bedroom, into the third floor hallway, down the open stairwell.  We glide through the entry floo still gently falling through the stairwell's airway, drop even further, all the way down to the kitchen floor, the ground floor. We drift across the darkened kitchen, serpentine through canyon of moving boxes, approach the window that looks ou the street. We move right up against the window, peer through the gla just as -- -- a van pulls up across the street and stops.  Can't see through its windows.  No movement for a moment, then the driver's door opens and a MAN climbs out.  He wears dark clothes. The Man closes the door, looks both ways, and starts acro the street towards us.  He's carrying a bag of some kind. He goes to the door, and we drift down toward the doorkno We hear a key slide into the door, rattle. But the lock doesn't turn.  The key slides out, back in again, jiggles.  Still won't open the door. The Man steps away from the door, goes to the kitchen win which is heavily barred, and peers inside, right at us. Can't see anything, it's darker in here than it is out th He turns, looks both ways on the street again, then steps onto the window ledge.  Now we can only see his legs, can tell what he's doing.  He's reaching up, stretching for something.  It drops into view with a metallic SCRAPE. The fire escape. The Man climbs, his feet disappearing from our field of vision. We turn around, facing the other way in the kitchen.  We start back the way we came, through the canyon of boxes i the kitchen, toward the stairwell.

Back in the stairwell, the exact reverse of the shot we s earlier.  We're drifting up, off the kitchen floor, throu the entry floor, and as we rise we notice something all t way up on the roof that we couldn't see before, when we w looking down. A skylight.  We continue to rise, drawn toward it.  We mo up, through the master bedroom floor, creeping up alongsi the stair banister, now reaching the top floor of the hou and just as we near the skylight -- -- a figure appears, visible through it.  The Man in dark clothes, on the roof now.  He stops, peers down through t skylight, looking at us without seeing us again. He steps across the skylight.  This is not the way he int to enter.  We drift again, following his soft footsteps o the roof, which we can hear faintly through the ceiling. Here in the hall, just outside Sarah's bedroom, a closet is ajar.  We squeeze through the gap and into the closet.

it's completely dark.  Can't see a thing.  But then a sli of light appears, coming from above.  We look up. There is a ladder that's bolted to the wall in this close it leads up to a square panel in the ceiling. Roof access.  And that roof access panel is moving, ever slightly, moonlight spilling in as it twists in its setti A shiny silver something slides through the crack along t edges of the portal. It slithers along the edge of the hatchway, searching for something.  It finds a small round nub in the crack.  The silver something stops.  It HUMS with electricity for a moment, then there is a bright spark and a soft CRACK.
In the master bedroom, a message appears on the alarm pan

In the closet, the silver something withdraws and the roo access panel is removed.  A million stars are visible in night sky above.  But we're inside. And in a moment, so is this intruder.  The Man peers down through the open hatchway, then slips through the opening climbs silently down the ladder.
In bed, Meg stirs.  An alcohol sleep is a restless one, a she's suffering. She sits up groggily, chugs a glass of water.  Lies down again.

One floor up, the Man steps into the hallway and starts f the stairs, moving quickly and confidently.  Knows where going, knows what he wants.  He starts down the stairs, happens to glance to the side as he does so. He freezes.  He's looking in the open doorway of the top floor bathroom, staring hard at something that clearly disturbs him. A nightlight.  Plugged into an outlet in the baseboard in bathroom.  (For the record, it's the Power Puff Girls.) Man climbs the stairs again, concerned, goes to the door the bathroom.  He looks from the nightlight to the countertop. There's a moving box on the countertop.  His eyes widen. This is news to him, bad news. He takes a step back and a breath.  He turns, looks to th end of the hall.  His eyes now adjusted to the darkness, notices something he didn't see before, something coming under the door to the fourth floor bedroom. Light.  From inside.  From another nightlight.

In the top floor bedroom, a nightlight burns in another outlet.  Nearby, Sarah is asleep in bed, the covers kicke off. The door to Sarah's bedroom glides open, terribly slowly. The Man stands in the doorway, staring, aghast, at the mountain of moving boxes piled in the room.  His gaze fal on Sarah in the bed. The Man just stares, beside himself.  His lips mouth a wo soundlessly.  Doesn't take a lip reader to guess it.

In the master bedroom, Meg flops over in bed, facing away from the doorway, really having a rough go of it.  She sl too hard before, now she's awake, her head is killing her she's really paying the price of four glasses of wine. She lies still, on her side, facing us. Behind her, the bedroom door moves, silently. Opening. The Man stands there, one finger still on the door he's j pushed open.  He stares at the sleeping form of Meg on th bed, whose back is to him.  He has no idea she's awake. Meg lies in bed, eyes wide open, no idea a Man is standin the doorway to her bedroom. Noiselessly, the Man moves away, down the hall.  The mome his head disappears down the stairwell -- -- Meg flops over again, facing the doorway.  She closes eyes, gives sleep another try.

The Man walks across the kitchen, shaking his head in exasperation at the packing boxes all around him.  He goe the front window, peers outside.  He reaches for a light switch on his right. Through the window, we can see the stoop light go on.  Th off, then on and off again. Still through the window, we see the side panel door of t van slide open. TWO MORE MEN climb out.  They are also dressed in dark clothes.  They also carry satchels. They walks calmly across the street, grow large in the wi as they approach us.  The first intruder (who has a name, it's BURNHAM) steps over to the kitchen door, runs his silvery strip through the gap.  Another HUM and spark.
flashes again.

Burnham opens the kitchen door, letting the two other guy slip inside.  RAOUL is a hulking figure whose back seems rise up over the top of his slouching head; when he walks looks like gravity does all the work, just pulling him forward.  JUNIOR is much smaller, very high-strung, dress like a homey, very street, but can't hide the fact that t street is Park Avenue. They all freeze, staring at the moving boxes.
Fuck.
I know.
What?
A woman and a little girl, both asleep upstairs.
Fuck!
Keep your voice down.
They're not supposed to be here!
This was your department, Junior.
They're not supposed to be here!
That's why the key didn't work, they changed the locks.
Fourteen day escrow, man, that's almost three weeks!  They shouldn't be here for another week!  They don't own this house yet!
(pause) Exactly how is fourteen days almost three weeks?
Fourteen business days.  Escrow is always business days.
Burnham sighs.
I mean, right?  Isn't it?
You're an idiot.
Raoul steps forward, shoves Burnham with both hands in th chest.
Watch your mouth.
It's okay, Raoul.
(to Junior) Who is this guy?
Raoul is cool.  That's all you need to know.
This is insane.  I'm outta here.
He starts for the door.
Wait a minute, wait a minute.  We can still handle this. (to Raoul) Can we still handle this?
It's just the woman and the kid?
Unless Daddy comes back later.
Daddy's not coming back, she's in the middle of a divorce, it's just the two of them.  We're okay, here. (to Raoul) We can do this, right?
You're fuckin' A we can do this.
Not with me.  Not with people.
Forty-five minutes.  That's all you said you need.  That's like nothing.
She'll call the cops, they'll be here before I get unpacked.
So we keep an eye on her.  Raoul can totally administrate that part.
No problem.
I don't want Raoul to administrate that part.
They won't get hurt.
What about us?  What if she has a gun?
Raoul, what in God's name do we do if she has a gun?
Raoul pulls up his sweatshirt, revealing a .38 tucked int his belt.
Asshole.
A guy shows you a gun, Burnham, and you insult him?  Hey, who's the idiot?  Huh?
Where did you get this clown?
I met him at the tables, same as you.  And frankly, I'm grateful we have a little muscle right about now.
What tables?  I've never seen him before.
Different tables.
(to Raoul) The fuck did you bring a gun for?
You're welcome.
Peace out.
He moves for the door.  Junior, trying desperately to hol this together, gets there first, blocks the door with his back.
We can't do it without you, Burnham.
Junior starts at Burnham.  Raoul stares at Burnham.
It's still a good plan.  It's just... got a twist.
Yeah.  Kidnapping.
Not if we keep 'em here.  You can't kidnap somebody in their own house. It's just breaking and entering, unless we take 'em someplace.  Or something like that, I'm pretty sure.
Pure idiot.

I am.  I'm an idiot's son.  An idiot's grandson.  I'm third- generation idiot.  But for once in my life I had a good idea, and I'm not giving up so easy.  You are? Are you actually telling me that for the first time in your life you're gonna throw your cards on the table and go home early?  I can't believe my eyes. (Burnham hesitates) Fourteen million dollars upstairs, Burnham.  You'll be out of the hole. Baby, you'll be so far out of the hole you could draw bricks every night for the next twenty years and still shit green. (Burnham sways) Come on, Buddy.  One more hand.

Meg sits up in bed.  She's bleary, her head feels like someone rested a manhole cover on it.  She gets up, in th dark, and staggers off toward the bathroom door, feeling way with her arms, her eyes not adjusted to the dark. She steps through the door.

She walks into the bathroom and feels around for a light switch, but can't find it.  She blinks, squints, tries to her bearings.  The only light is a harsh white glow that comes from along one wall, from a bank of tiny video monitors. She finds the light switch, flicks it on, it nearly blind her.  She's not in the bathroom.  She's wandered into the panic room by mistake. She turns around, walks out, leaving the lights on behind her. We linger for a look at the video screens.  If only she'd done the same, she'd see what we see.
we see the three men, still in the kitchen, huddled in a group, silently debating what to do.
Using the light that spills from the open door to the pan room, Meg comes back into the master bedroom and finds th proper door to the bathroom.

Meg SNAPS the cap off a jug of Advil and dumps three into palm.  She pops them in her mouth, searches for a glass f water, finds none, bends to the spout for a gulp to wash down. She turns to the toilet.
On the monitor, we see the three men leave the kitchen an start up the stairs.
Meg stands, flushes the toilet.

One floor down, Burnham, Raoul, and Junior freeze, just coming up the stairs from the kitchen.  They look up, hea the water rushing through the pipes in the ceiling direct above them. They stare at the ceiling, following with their eyes as a pair of feet pad across the CREAKY floor.  Finally, they a SQUEAK of bedsprings as Meg climbs back into bed. They hold a moment longer, a silence grows.  Raoul reache into his jacket pocket and pulls out a ski mask.  He pull over his head.  They look at him.
(whispers) No face.
Burnham rolls his eyes.  Doesn't know this guy much, but hates him so far.  They start across the foyer toward the stairs.
Meg rolls over, to go back to sleep.  She sees she's left lights on in the panic room.  She TSKS, gets out of bed, walks across the floor toward it.

Meg steps into the panic room, raises her hand to the lig switch -- -- and stops, her hand frozen in mid-air.  She cocks her head, looking at something she can't understand. She blinks.  Takes a step, further into the room.  She st at the video monitors -- at the three men in dark clothes stealing silently across the foyer. This can't be.  These are just pictures, they have no relation to reality.  She drops to her knees, her face in from the screens, and reaches out to touch them, as if tr to make sure they're really there.
They reach the base of the stairs, Junior in the lead.  A reaches a bend at the base of the stairs, he places one f short on an angled step and it slips off.  He trips, fall forward.

Watching the video monitors, Meg stares in horror as the image of Junior slipping is verified by the SLAP of his h on the stairs as he catches himself, audible through the door to the panic room. She GASPS.  It is real.
In the living room, Burnham's eyes are wide as saucers, staring at Junior as he turns and pulls himself to his fe Junior points at Raoul, speaks in an urgent whisper.
Top floor, get the little girl and keep her there.  I'll bring the woman up.  Gimme.
He holds out his hand for the gun and Raoul gives it to h
(points to Burnham) Stay here.  Nobody gets past you.
He heads for the stairs.  Raoul follows close behind him. Burnham stays, reluctant -- what the fuck has he gotten himself into?
Meg moves.  Leaps to her feet and dashes out of the room.
Meg races across her bedroom, flies out the door, and bol up the carpeted stairs, headed for the top floor.
Meg races into Sarah's room, drops onto the bed, and grab Sarah by the shoulders, trying to rouse her.
Wake up... wake up...
But she's in a profound child's sleep and won't wake up.

One floor down, Junior and Raoul reach the third floor landing.  Still moving stealthily, Junior heads down the for the master bedroom, where he thinks Meg is sleeping. Raoul heads for the stairs that lead to the top floor.
Meg is desperate, still can't wake Sarah.
Wake up...come on, come on...
She sees a plastic cup on her night table/box, half fille with water.  She snatches it and tosses the water in her face. Now she's awake.  And pissed off.  She SPUTTERS, SHOUTS.
WHAT DID YOU DO THAT FOR?!
Raoul, at the base of the stairs that lead to the top flo hears the kid shouting.  He starts up the stairs, quickly
On the top floor, Meg is already dragging Sarah out of th room and into the hallway.

Meg and Sarah come out of Sarah's bedroom just as Raoul reaches the top of the stairs at the other end.  They're off. Meg freezes, staring at the hulking ski-masked figure at end of the hallway.  She thinks, no idea what to do for a second.  She looks frantically to her right -- the bathro dead end. She looks to her left. The elevator. She yanks open the elevator door, throws aside the gate, races inside with Sarah. Raoul takes off down the hall, lunging for the elevator.
Meg SLAMS the gate shut and PUNCHES the button for the fi floor.  The elevator GROANS to life and starts down -- slowly. Sarah looks up at her, terrified.
What's going on?!
People.  In the house.
As the elevator descends, they see Raoul, through the win in the door, as he drops to his knees, to get a good look them.
Raoul turns from the elevator, SHOUTS to the open stairwe
